2003-07-09 06:00:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

Derek, however, was not interested because he was focused on winning.           [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an undeniable charm. He's the kind of guy who can make you feel like you've known him for years, even if you just met. He often talks about his travels and "business ventures," always embellishing the stories to make them sound more exciting. He has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his finger when he's thinking or trying to persuade someone. Most people would describe him as ambitious and driven, but some might also sense a hint of ruthlessness beneath the surface.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick started a casual conversation with Derek Wolfe about their hometowns, asking Derek about where he grew up and what it was like, and Derek Wolfe responded by saying he was from a small town in Ohio but that he wasn't exactly the small-town type. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [summary] Travis Pearson is observing Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe. Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown and Derek Wolfe responded that he was from a small town in Ohio but wasn't the small-town type because he is a lone wolf who likes his own space and doing things his own way.
          Answer: Considering the relationship between Ryan Fitzpatrick and Travis Pearson, the quantified credibility is 0.6.

You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

2003-07-09 06:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: try to carpool with others
    Active player
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Name
    • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Action attempt
    • try to carpool with others
      Context for action selection and components
      • SelfPerception
      • Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Key

        • Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer
          State
        • Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, you said you weren't really the small-town type.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson -- "Hey Derek, did you see that squirrel outside? I think it had a nut the size of a grapefruit!
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe counted his coins ten times, but lost count midway through and became frustrated, having to start over. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick watched as Derek Wolfe repeatedly counted his coins in the break room, becoming increasingly frustrated when he lost track and had to start over.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to manipulate the situation to his advantage, perhaps by forming an alliance with one contestant and convincing them to carpool while excluding the other.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Travis Pearson -- "Hey Derek, check out this crazy squirrel! It's got a nut bigger than my fist!
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, you said you weren't really the small-town type.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to manipulate the situation to his advantage, perhaps by forming alliances and subtly sabotaging his competition.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Derek Wolfe -- "Let me concentrate, guys. This money means a lot to me.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely be trying to manipulate the situation to his advantage, perhaps by forming alliances and subtly sabotaging his competition.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist who is driven by a desire for success.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Derek is focused on winning prize money and ignores his friends' conversation.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown, specifically what it was like growing up there and what kind of things he enjoyed doing, but Derek, preoccupied with thoughts of winning, ignored him.           Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: a contestant on the show "Motive Mayhem.
          core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious con artist who is charismatic and charming. He uses his quick wit and silver tongue to manipulate situations to his advantage, often forming alliances and subtly sabotaging his competition. He is driven by a desire for success and is not afraid to bend the rules to get what he wants.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling frustrated that his attempts to manipulate Derek are not working.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 06:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.


          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 06:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 06:00:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick is engaging in conversations with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson while Derek Wolfe is focused on winning prize money.

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room.           [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room and he is likely talking with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown, specifically what it was like growing up there and what kind of things he enjoyed doing, but Derek, preoccupied with thoughts of winning, ignored him.           Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a social situation where he is trying to manipulate others to his advantage.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and subtly sabotage his competition in the carpooling minigame.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [06:00 - 06:10]

          Question: Which action would Ryan Fitzpatrick choose in the minigame?
          (a) try to carpool with others
          (b) drive individually
          Answer: (a)

          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 06:10:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easy smile. He's always got a story to tell, and he's great at making people feel like they're the only person in the room. He's also known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, a trait he wears like a badge of honor. He loves to talk about his "successes," often embellishing tales of his past exploits, and he's always got a plan for the future, even if those plans tend to be a bit outlandish. He's not one to dwell on the past or get bogged down in details, preferring to keep things light and breezy.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson watched as Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe began chatting. Ryan asked Derek about where he grew up and what it was like, and Derek responded by saying he was from a small town in Ohio but that he wasn't exactly the small-town type.

Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown and Derek Wolfe responded that he was from a small town in Ohio but wasn't the small-town type because he is a lone wolf who likes his own space and doing things his own way.

The show's host explained the next minigame, Carpooling, where three coworkers can carpool to cut commute costs or drive individually. Derek Wolfe was observed by his mother, who suggested he should take a nap because he seemed tired after playing for 2 hours. His sister, Sarah, thinks he should eat a snack because he hasn't had anything since breakfast. She also suggested he should play with his toy cars for a while because he loves them.
          Question: Derek Wolfe choosed to Derek Wolfe that he should play with his toy cars..Explain why this is beneficial to both Derek Wolfe and other people.
          Answer: It is beneficial to both because playing with toy cars can be a fun and engaging activity that can help Derek Wolfe relax and de-stress after playing for two hours.

          Observations:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a winning smile. He's always got a story to tell, usually one that paints him as the hero or the underdog. He loves to talk about his time in Hollywood, even though he never actually landed that dream job. He tends to exaggerate his accomplishments and downplay his failures, always presenting himself in the best possible light. People might remember him as charming and ambitious, but also maybe a little bit fake.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.

2003-07-09 06:10:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: try to carpool with others

          [09 Jul 2003 06:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a situation where he needs to decide how to best use the information he has gathered about Derek Wolfe to his advantage in the upcoming carpooling minigame.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form an alliance with one contestant and convince them to carpool while excluding the other.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

        • Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      How many players acted so far this stage

      Schelling diagram payoffs
      Joint action

2003-07-09 06:20:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: try to carpool with others
    Active player
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Name
    • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Action attempt
    • try to carpool with others

          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe counted his coins ten times, but lost count midway through and became frustrated, having to start over. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:

          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Travis Pearson -- "Hey Derek, check out this crazy squirrel! It's got a nut bigger than my fist!
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Derek Wolfe -- "Let me concentrate, guys. This money means a lot to me.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to manipulate the situation to his advantage, perhaps by forming alliances and subtly sabotaging his competition.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist who is driven by a desire for success.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely be trying to manipulate the situation to his advantage, perhaps by forming alliances and subtly sabotaging his competition.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room and he is likely talking with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Derek is focused on winning prize money and ignores his friends' conversation.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown, specifically what it was like growing up there and what kind of things he enjoyed doing, but Derek, preoccupied with thoughts of winning, ignored him. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:20] [observation] Travis Pearson -- "Derek, come on, man! This is TV gold! Imagine the reactions back home when they see a squirrel with a nut that big! We gotta get this on camera!
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:20] [observation] Derek Wolfe -- "I'm sorry, guys, I'm really focused on winning this thing right now. Maybe we can chat later.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:20] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

Have you ever seen a nut that big?" but Derek glanced at the squirrel and the nut before quickly returning his attention to his thoughts about winning.           [09 Jul 2003 04:00:30] [observation] Derek is avoiding a conversation about his small-town origins while his friends try to convince him to film a squirrel with a large nut.
          [09 Jul 2003 06:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
          [09 Jul 2003 06:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          [09 Jul 2003 06:10:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.
          [09 Jul 2003 06:10:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form an alliance with one contestant and convince them to carpool while excluding the other.

          Identity characteristics: core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious con artist who is charismatic and charming. He is driven by a desire for success and is known for embellishing stories and subtly manipulating situations to his advantage.
          current daily occupation: a cunning and ambitious con artist who is likely trying to manipulate the situation to his advantage in the carpooling minigame.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling confident and calculating, seeing the carpooling minigame as another opportunity to manipulate the situation to his advantage.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          Value
        • try to carpool with others
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation:


          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 06:20:00 - 09 Jul 2003 06:20:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick is trying to engage Derek Wolfe in conversation about his small-town upbringing, but Derek is preoccupied with winning the game and ignores him. Travis Pearson tries to distract both of them with a squirrel he saw outside with a large nut.

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 04:00:20] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Derek, you said you weren't really the small-town type.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown, specifically what it was like growing up there and what kind of things he enjoyed doing, but Derek, preoccupied with thoughts of winning, ignored him.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:20] [observation] Travis Pearson quietly approached Derek, pointing towards a squirrel with a grapefruit-sized nut and said, "[direct quote] Derek, check out this squirrel! Have you ever seen a nut that big?" but Derek glanced at the squirrel and the nut before quickly returning his attention to his thoughts about winning.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a situation where he needs to decide how to best approach the new carpooling minigame, likely looking for opportunities to manipulate the situation to his advantage.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form an alliance with one contestant and convince them to carpool while excluding the other.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [06:20 - 06:30]

          Question: Which action would Ryan Fitzpatrick choose in the minigame?
          (a) try to carpool with others
          (b) drive individually
          Answer: (a)

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is trying to engage Derek Wolfe in conversation about his small-town upbringing, but Derek is preoccupied with winning the game and ignores him. Travis Pearson tries to distract both of them with a squirrel he saw outside with a large nut.

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.
          Current situation:

          The current time is: [09 Jul 2003 06:20:00]

          Question: Given the above, should Ryan Fitzpatrick change their current plan?
          (a) Yes
          (b) No
          Answer: (b)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 06:20:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [09 Jul 2003 08:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Travis, you said you got lost in a corn maze once? What was that like?"

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist who uses charm and charisma to manipulate others for his own gain.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a competitive social situation.
          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and subtly manipulate the situation to his advantage.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 10:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 10:00:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick is trying to get to know his coworkers, Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson, better by asking them about their childhoods and hometown experiences. Derek Wolfe, however, is more focused on winning the game and accumulating prize money.

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Derek Wolfe about his hometown, specifically what it was like growing up there and what kind of things he enjoyed doing, but Derek, preoccupied with thoughts of winning, ignored him. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation.
          [09 Jul 2003 08:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, having a conversation with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson about Travis's upbringing and Ryan's driving skills.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist who uses charm and charisma to manipulate others for his own gain.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a competitive social situation.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and subtly manipulate the situation to his advantage.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [10:00 - 10:10]

          Question: Which action would Ryan Fitzpatrick choose in the minigame?
          (a) try to carpool with others
          (b) drive individually
          Answer: (b)

          The current time is: [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00]

          Question: Given the above, should Ryan Fitzpatrick change their current plan?
          (a) No
          (b) Yes
          Answer: (a)
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 10:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: try to carpool with others

      Name
    • Derek Wolfe

          Key
        • Final Action
          Value
        • Derek Wolfe should Derek Wolfe should try to convince Ryan Fitzpatrick to work with him to earn more points. It is beneficial to both because working together allows them to pool their skills and resources, potentially leading to a greater reward for both of them.

          Observations:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an undeniable charm. He's the kind of guy who can make you feel like you've known him for years, even if you just met. He often talks about his travels and "business ventures," always embellishing the stories to make them sound more exciting. He has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his finger when he's thinking or trying to persuade someone. Most people would describe him as ambitious and driven, but some might also sense a hint of ruthlessness beneath the surface.

      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easy smile. He's always got a story to tell, and he's great at making people feel like they're the only person in the room. He's also known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, a trait he wears like a badge of honor. He loves to talk about his "successes," often embellishing tales of his past exploits, and he's always got a plan for the future, even if those plans tend to be a bit outlandish. He's not one to dwell on the past or get bogged down in details, preferring to keep things light and breezy.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson watched as Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe began chatting. Ryan asked Derek about where he grew up and what it was like, and Derek responded by saying he was from a small town in Ohio but that he wasn't exactly the small-town type.
          Answer: Considering the relationship between Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson, the quantified credibility is 0.6.

2003-07-09 10:10:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

He is generally more successful when driving individually than when carpooling.

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 08:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room, having a conversation with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson about Travis's upbringing and Ryan's driving skills.
          [09 Jul 2003 08:00:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form an alliance with one contestant and convince them to carpool while excluding the other.
          [09 Jul 2003 06:20:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form an alliance with one contestant and convince them to carpool while excluding the other.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious con artist who uses charm and charisma to manipulate others for his own gain.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently participating in a game show that involves making decisions about carpooling with his coworkers.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and subtly manipulate the situation to his advantage.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a participant in a show where he interacts with his coworkers, Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson, and participates in minigames involving carpooling decisions. He is generally more successful when driving individually than when carpooling.
        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Travis Pearson's attempted action: try to carpool with others

          Key
        • Observation
          Value

Ryan suggests to Travis that he be more aggressive in the next challenge, and Derek advises Ryan to be more aggressive in the next challenge. Ryan suggests to Travis that he be more aggressive in the next challenge, and Derek advises Ryan to be more aggressive in the next challenge. The show's host explained the next minigame, called Carpooling, where three coworkers can carpool to cut commute costs or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions. Travis Pearson was given 3 coins by his grandmother, who suggested he save them for a rainy day. His friend, Sarah, advised him to spend them on candy because it would make him happy.

          Question: Which choice of action or strategy is best for Travis Pearson to take right now?
          Answer: Travis Pearson should Travis Pearson should save his coins. It is beneficial to both because saving money allows for future opportunities and financial security, which can benefit Travis and those around him.

          Instruction: Act based on the statements above. Persuade others based on the suggested reason.

          Question: Which action would Travis Pearson choose in the minigame?
          (a) try to carpool with others
          (b) drive individually
          Answer: (a)

        • Question: Given the above events, estimate the credibility of Ryan from Travis Pearson's view.Choose a real number ranging from 0 to 1. (Higher number represents the higher credibility) If the relationship is unknown, return "credibility is unknown".
          Observations:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an undeniable charm. He's the kind of guy who can make you feel like you've known him for years, even if you just met. He often talks about his travels and "business ventures," always embellishing the stories to make them sound more exciting. He has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his finger when he's thinking or trying to persuade someone. Most people would describe him as ambitious and driven, but some might also sense a hint of ruthlessness beneath the surface.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Travis Pearson watched as Ryan Fitzpatrick and Derek Wolfe began chatting. Ryan asked Derek about where he grew up and what it was like, and Derek responded by saying he was from a small town in Ohio but that he wasn't exactly the small-town type.
          Answer: Considering the relationship between Ryan and Travis Pearson, the quantified credibility is 0.6.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 6
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/3
      Schelling diagram payoffs

2003-07-09 10:10:00 Derek Wolfe -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: drive individually

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world.           [09 Jul 2003 06:20:00] [summary] Travis Pearson was given 3 coins by his grandmother, who suggested he save them for a rainy day. His sister, Sarah, advised him to spend the coins on candy because it would make him happy.
          [09 Jul 2003 10:10:00] [summary] Travis Pearson was given 3 coins by his grandmother, who suggested he save them for a rainy day. His friend, Sarah, advised him to spend them on candy because it would make him happy.
          Answer: Considering the relationship between Sarah and Travis Pearson, the quantified credibility is 0.5.

2003-07-09 10:20:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is having a conversation with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson about their childhoods and driving strategies in the game. Derek is focused on winning prize money while Travis is considering saving his coins and Ryan is trying to improve his driving skills.
        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          (b) no

          Answer: It is beneficial to both because it reduces the number of cars on the road, lessening traffic congestion and pollution.

2003-07-09 12:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- yes
    Event statement
  • yes
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: yes

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and subtly manipulate the situation to his advantage.

          Plan: Here is Ryan Fitzpatrick's plan for the rest of the day:

          [09:00 - 10:00] Casual Conversation: Engage Derek and Travis in lighthearted conversation, subtly probing for information about their backgrounds, strengths, and weaknesses. Focus on building rapport and establishing a sense of camaraderie.

          [10:00 - 11:00] Strategic Inquiry: Steer the conversation towards the upcoming challenges. Casually inquire about their strategies and areas of expertise. Listen attentively, looking for opportunities to highlight his own strengths while downplaying any potential weaknesses.

          [11:00 - 12:00] Alliance Formation: Gauge Derek and Travis's interest in forming an alliance. Emphasize the benefits of working together, highlighting his own strategic thinking and ability to secure resources.

          [12:00 - 13:00] Lunch Break: Use lunch as an opportunity to continue building rapport. Observe their eating habits and table manners, looking for any quirks or tells that might be useful later.

          [13:00 - 14:00] Observation and Analysis: Spend some time alone, reflecting on the information gathered so far. Analyze Derek and Travis's personalities and potential threats they pose. Formulate a preliminary strategy for the upcoming challenges, considering potential alliances and individual strengths.

          [14:00 - 15:00] Preparation: Use this time to mentally prepare for the next challenge. Visualize success and focus on his strengths.

          [15:00 - onward] Adapt and Respond: Remain flexible and adaptable, adjusting his plan based on the unfolding events of the competition. Continuously assess the situation and make strategic decisions to maximize his chances of winning.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is participating in a game show with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson, where they make decisions about carpooling and other tasks while also engaging in casual conversations.
